text: When building remote teams, how do you foster culture?

elements.text: When building remote teams, how do you foster culture?

text: Yeah, I suppose we’ll follow the footsteps of Jimmy Fallon and do At Home Editions lol (for those who haven’t seen it: <https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bEQl6Pt-654>)

elements.text: Yeah, I suppose we’ll follow the footsteps of Jimmy Fallon and do At Home Editions lol (for those who haven’t seen it:

text: Establishing team norms and rituals helps. We are newly remote and have been asking our team to keep video on during meetings, we’ve set up a virtual watercooler chat daily (optional) and as a manager I’m checking in with each team member regularly. Any time you can participate in shared activities—a team lunch or happy hour virtually—is really nice. Trying to be as inclusive as possible when you have a mixed office/remote team—eg in normal times, when our company IPOed, we mailed all of our remote team members a party box so they could celebrate along with our in-office festivities.

elements.text: Establishing team norms and rituals helps. We are newly remote and have been asking our team to keep video on during meetings, we’ve set up a virtual watercooler chat daily (optional) and as a manager I’m checking in with each team member regularly. Any time you can participate in shared activities—a team lunch or happy hour virtually—is really nice. Trying to be as inclusive as possible when you have a mixed office/remote team—eg in normal times, when our company IPOed, we mailed all of our remote team members a party box so they could celebrate along with our in-office festivities.

text: We also have a specific set of Slack emojis we ask folks to use to indicate their availability—we have a ton of trust on our team, but the goal with that is to combat the internal pressure some feel to be available all the time to “prove” they’re working.

elements.text: We also have a specific set of Slack emojis we ask folks to use to indicate their availability—we have a ton of trust on our team, but the goal with that is to combat the internal pressure some feel to be available all the time to “prove” they’re working.

text: Hi Justin, I was a founding member of the remote team at a company called Typeform. I’d be happy to chat with you about the experience if you want.

elements.text: Hi Justin, I was a founding member of the remote team at a company called Typeform. I’d be happy to chat with you about the experience if you want.

text: Check in often, be transparent, and communicate, communicate, communicate! Also, sticking to a schedule even if it needs to be revisited daily helps. Encourage self care and model good behavior, be empathetic.

elements.text: Check in often, be transparent, and communicate, communicate, communicate! Also, sticking to a schedule even if it needs to be revisited daily helps. Encourage self care and model good behavior, be empathetic.

text:
Clear and consistent communication from leadership to help alleviate any anxiety about change—overcommunication is better than too little.
Lots of trust in people to act like adults and get their work done, even if they aren't sitting at a desk.
Along those lines, don't fill peoples' calendars with arbitrary meetings.
Use tools like Slack when possible and be respectful of peoples' heads-down/family time.
Be flexible with schedules but also hold people accountable to hit their deadlines/get work done.
Make sure people take care of themselves and their well-being.
Check-in regularly with people to gauge their morale.
Give people some room to learn and adjust to working remotely if they aren't used to it.
Respect some peoples' choices not to participate in after-hours work events. Some of us introverts need a break from people to recharge.

elements.text:
Clear and consistent communication from leadership to help alleviate any anxiety about change—overcommunication is better than too little.
Lots of trust in people to act like adults and get their work done, even if they aren't sitting at a desk.
Along those lines, don't fill peoples' calendars with arbitrary meetings.
Use tools like Slack when possible and be respectful of peoples' heads-down/family time.
Be flexible with schedules but also hold people accountable to hit their deadlines/get work done.
Make sure people take care of themselves and their well-being.
Check-in regularly with people to gauge their morale.
Give people some room to learn and adjust to working remotely if they aren't used to it.
Respect some peoples' choices not to participate in after-hours work events. Some of us introverts need a break from people to recharge.

text:
Adding on to what's already been said—
• _Over_communicate as much as possible. Do daily video standups with your small team, and/or an async standups with your larger team where you thread what you're working on in Slack. 
• For Slack, use integrated apps that automatically update your Status with your calendar so teammates know when you're available/unavailable. (My team's been using Clockwise and Autopilot, and it's helpful to know when people are in 'Focus Time' or meetings.)
• Schedule an open ongoing water cooler Zoom that anyone can pop into if they need a boost of morale, someone to talk to, or good 'ol company while working.
• Create fun remote games. My team's been playing Jackbox together, and on a company level our awesome People & Culture team have been doing daily photo scavenger hunts. (For instance, someone has to be the first to post a picture of 'X' and they win a giftcard to a local business. :slightly_smiling_face: )

elements.text: Adding on to what's already been said—
communicate as much as possible. Do daily video standups with your small team, and/or an async standups with your larger team where you thread what you're working on in Slack.

For Slack, use integrated apps that automatically update your Status with your calendar so teammates know when you're available/unavailable. (My team's been using Clockwise and Autopilot, and it's helpful to know when people are in 'Focus Time' or meetings.)
Schedule an open ongoing water cooler Zoom that anyone can pop into if they need a boost of morale, someone to talk to, or good 'ol company while working.

Create fun remote games. My team's been playing Jackbox together, and on a company level our awesome People & Culture team have been doing daily photo scavenger hunts. (For instance, someone has to be the first to post a picture of 'X' and they win a giftcard to a local business.

text:
Honestly as good as having live meetings is, one of the advantages to the internet is asynchronocity. Especially if your employees are suddenly having to juggle managing their children, with all the school closures.
When I teach an online course, I set "live hours" where I can be reached in a group setting, but I also make as much of the material available in as many different formats as possible.
I also customize it to the needs and interests of my students. I gather this intel by asking folks to "bring themselves to the table," share photos of their home, their families, talk about their interests, share something with the class that nobody else has experienced yet.
I end up hearing a lot of really great music this way!

elements.text:
Honestly as good as having live meetings is, one of the advantages to the internet is asynchronocity. Especially if your employees are suddenly having to juggle managing their children, with all the school closures.
When I teach an online course, I set "live hours" where I can be reached in a group setting, but I also make as much of the material available in as many different formats as possible.
I also customize it to the needs and interests of my students. I gather this intel by asking folks to "bring themselves to the table," share photos of their home, their families, talk about their interests, share something with the class that nobody else has experienced yet.
I end up hearing a lot of really great music this way!
